awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Extreme-scale Ready High-order Methods for Astrophysical and Laboratory Turbulence
awd_abstract_narration:
Astrophysical phenomena inherently involve multi-physics and multi-scales that are nonlinearly coupled.  The mathematical accuracy and efficiency of the computational tools used to test theoretical models hugely impact the scientific outcomes.  The astrophysics community has thus long focused on developing computationally accurate numerical algorithms that give improved solution accuracy, stability, and efficiency.  This project tackles the challenge of developing new approaches to address these problems, and incorporating these methods in the FLASH community code in order to reach a large audience in the astrophysics community.  The work lies at the nexus of applied and computational mathematics, statistical Gaussian Process (GP) data predictions, and astrophysics.  Involvement in NSF-supported outreach will help to educate under-represented community college students in computational astrophysics.  Training young scientists in astrophysical and laboratory turbulence using validated simulations also helps to meet a critical national need.

This study will develop high-order accurate, novel algorithms with only modest complexity, using a new high-order GP spatial reconstruction approach and a novel single-step high-order temporal integration method.  This powerful predictive tool will run on massively parallel high-performance architectures.  The study involves, firstly, using the novel GP approach to overcome the second-order bottleneck in most finite-volume shock-capturing astrophysics codes.  The GP algorithms provide a simple mathematical framework for computing highly accurate volume-averaged versus pointwise quantities, and multidimensional spatial reconstructions.  The second important development is an efficient high-order temporal integration method in adaptive mesh refinement grid configurations.  This requires a single-step time update at a single quadrature point per cell face, which will provide the most efficient algorithmic framework in extreme-scale parallel simulations.  Finally, comparing simulation results based on solution accuracy, errors, and computational performance for key astrophysical flow problems, including astrophysical and laboratory turbulence, will demonstrate the impact and benefit of these advances.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Context 

Astrophysical phenomena involve multi-physics non-linear processes that occur at multiple scales. To study their nature, modern computational plasma physics and astrophysics rely on computational tools which must be tested through rigorous validation and verification. The accuracy and computational efficiency of such numerical tools have substantial impact on scientific outcomes. The challenge involves developing high-order accurate numerical algorithms for computer simulations while keeping their complexity modest. This project tackled these challenges with a new class of high-order Gaussian Process (GP) spatial reconstruction/interpolation methods. The verification and validation of the new methods leverages applications in astrophysical turbulence and fluctuation dynamo, in both large-scale driven-turbulence simulations and laser-driven laboratory astrophysics experiments. The latter, reported here, were performed by PI Tzeferacos under the auspices of NSF PHY-2033925, and U.S. DOE NNSA DE-NA0003934, in the context of the TDYNO (turbulent dynamo) collaboration, co-led by the University of Rochester and the University of Oxford, which demonstrated fluctuation dynamo in the laboratory for the first time through concerted numerical simulations and laser-driven experiments [1] at the Omega Laser Facility at the Laboratory for Laser Energetics (LLE) of the University of Rochester (APS-DPP John Dawson Award for Excellence in Plasma Physics Research, 2019).

Intellectual Merit

The experiments associated with this project include TDYNO campaigns at the LLE and the Laser Megajoule Facility (LMJ) in France. We designed these experiments through simulation campaigns using FLASH [2], a multi-physics [3], magneto-hydrodynamics [4] simulation code the Flash Center for Computational Science develops [5]. The simulations guided experimental platform design to ensure that the experiments achieve the desired plasma conditions; informed the timing and configuration of the experimental diagnostics; and enabled the interpretation of the results of the experiments.

The first set of experiments at the LLE yielded the first time-resolved characterization of fluctuation dynamo in a laser plasma [6]. The experiments realized a turbulent plasma with magnetic Prandtl numbers of order unity, Pm~1, relevant to many astrophysical environments such as the intracluster medium of galaxy clusters. The time-resolved characterization of the plasma evolution allowed us to explore the various stages of the fluctuation dynamo mechanism. We find that magnetic energy in structures with characteristic scales close to the driving scale of the stochastic motions increases by almost three orders of magnitude and saturates dynamically, matching the FLASH predictions. The initial growth rate of the amplified magnetic fields is also found to be much greater than the turnover rate of the driving-scale stochastic motions. Our results indicate that plasma turbulence produced by strong shear can generate fields more efficiently at the driving scale than anticipated by idealized magneto-hydrodynamic simulations of nonhelical fluctuation dynamo, a finding that could help explain large-scale fields inferred from observations.

Further, the TDYNO collaboration conducted experiments at the Laser Megajoule Facility (LMJ) in France (the first academic experiment at LMJ) to demonstrate, for the first time, magnetic field amplification in supersonic turbulence [7]. Using FLASH simulations, we ported the TDYNO platform to LMJ and leveraged the radiative properties of the aluminum plasma to decrease the sound speed and create compressible, magnetized turbulence, and demonstrated experimentally the creation and modest amplification of turbulent magnetic fields. Our results are broadly consistent with the expectation that magnetic-field amplification is less efficient in supersonic, low-Pm turbulence, as compared to moderate-Pm subsonic turbulence. Follow-on experiments at LLE in FY24, again designed with FLASH, demonstrated for the first time that supersonic turbulence is capable of fluctuation dynamo action [8]. An article is in preparation supported by NSF PHY-2308844. 

Broader impacts

The simulation and experimental effort associated with the TDYNO experimental campaigns supported the training of early-career scientists in the design, execution, and interpretation of High Energy Density Physics (HEDP) experiments using validated FLASH simulations. The Flash Center engaged five graduate students, three postdocs, and five undergraduate students, who were involved in activities that have significantly enhanced their research experience and advanced their scientific skills. Through the close interfacing of numerical modeling and experimental work, we enhanced, verified, and validated the capabilities of FLASH to enable higher fidelity simulations of laser-driven experiments. These capabilities were made widely available in the public releases of the FLASH code through the Flash Center website [5]. The project furthered the Flash Center's efforts to transform the academic community's ability to use numerical simulations to design and analyze HEDP experiments at large laser facilities. This was made possible by the availability of FLASH and its adoption by the academic HEDP research community. 

Products

Bott et al. PNAS, 118:e2015729118, 2021.

Bott et al. PRL, 127:175002, 2021.

[2] Fryxell et al. APJS, 131:273, 2000.

[3] Tzeferacos et al. HEDP, 17:24, 2015.

[4] Lee.  JCP, 243:269, 2013.
